conclusion: Place A at the origin, AB on the positive x-axis, AC on the positive y-axis.
Let |AB| = 1 (any scale factor finally cancels); then |AC| = tan 60° ⋅ |AB| = √3, |BC| = 2 (by 30–60–90 triangle).
EG ⟂ AC and meets BC at G; D is the midpoint of CG.
Parametrize BC: B(1,0) → C(0,√3). A point with parameter t (0 ≤ t ≤ 1) is P(t) = (1–t, √3 t).
Let G = P(tG). Because EG ⟂ AC (the y-axis), EG is horizontal, so G has the same y-coordinate as E, and E lies on AC (the y-axis). Thus G = (xG, yG) with yG = yE.
C is (0,√3), G is (1–tG, √3 tG). The midpoint condition for D: D = ((0+1–tG)/2, (√3+√3 tG)/2).
Reflection law: incident angle = reflected angle with respect to AC (the y-axis).
Since AC is vertical, reflection across AC simply reverses the x-component of the ray; the y-component stays unchanged.
Hence: slope of DE is m1; after reflection slope of EF is –m1.
AB is horizontal, so reflection across AB changes the y-component’s sign; slope changes from –m1 to +m1.
EF hits AB at F, exits making the same angle with AB as EF makes on the inside.
Deviation = external deflection of the ray at D (between the incident part in air and the first segment inside the prism).
Call θ the angle DE makes with AC. Because reflection at AC reverses the x-component, the incident ray must also make θ with AC but on the other side.
From similar triangles (30–60–90 proportions) and the midpoint condition one obtains tan θ = 1/√3.
